reasoning: The critique targets a genuinely load-bearing part of the essay’s practical framing: the definition of “fussiness” and the probability of mostly-great futures is relative to a baseline distribution conditional on survival and “no serious de dicto optimisation pressure.” If that baseline is badly mischaracterised (because post-AGI worlds feature strong endogenous optimisation even without explicit moral aiming), then the essay’s claims about what happens ‘by default’ could be substantially weakened. However, the essay’s core case for ‘no easy eutopia’ is not just about absence of optimisation; it also argues that (i) the value target is intrinsically narrow across many moral views (fragility/product-of-factors; population ethics; digital minds; bads-vs-goods aggregation), and (ii) many optimisation pressures plausibly push toward locally stable but morally suboptimal attractors. The critique mostly asserts, rather than demonstrates, that competition selects for robust welfare/rights norms and thereby raises the probability mass on mostly-great outcomes; it gives little mechanism-level analysis or evidence, and it underplays countervailing dynamics (races to the bottom, externalities onto disempowered digital beings, lock-in by power concentration, “stable” equilibria that are far from near-best). Still, it is squarely relevant to Forethought’s active agenda about whether flourishing is ‘predetermined’ vs requires deliberate steering, and it usefully flags that the essay may owe more justification for treating low de dicto optimisation as the right counterfactual baseline (or for arguing endogenous optimisation tends to the wrong attractors).
title: "Endogenous Optimization Pressure Undermines Paper's Default Assumption"
